item.title: Introducing the European Labour Authority: A New EU Agency Based in Bratislava
item.description:
Bartłomiej Bednarowicz, PhD Researcher at the Faculty of Law of the University of Antwerp Background Bratislava was chosen by the Council to host the headquarters of the newly established European Labour Authority (ELA). Initially proposed by President Juncker in 2017, the ELA’s primary goal is to simplify and enhance the fairness of EU labor mobility within the internal market. This initiative stemmed from the European Pillar of Social Rights (EPSR) and was introduced alongside other measures aimed at promoting social fairness within the EU...

item.title: Do Member States have the authority to make decisions that are above the law? Is it possible to challenge Member States' decisions regarding the locations of EU agencies?
item.description:
Ezio Perillo, formerly a judge on the EU General Court and the EU civil service tribunal, argues that decisions made by EU Member States regarding the locations of European agencies may not be subject to judicial review by the EU Court. This is based on the Sharpston-Council orders (cases C-684/20P and C-685/20P), which deemed the former British Advocate General’s challenge against a new AG appointment inadmissible, and Advocate General Bobek’s opinion in joined cases concerning the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Labour Authority (ELA) (cases C-59/18, C-182/18, and C-743/19, and in a parallel opinion in Cases C-106/19 and 232/19)...
